merge_entries.reasoning: These all refer to the general practice of implementing circular economy approaches in construction/deconstruction. 'Culture' and 'Transition' are aspects of the broader practice.

Both refer to the same training practice. Training is something people DO (a Practice), not a policy instrument.
All three refer to the same barrier: absence of regulatory frameworks for circular economy.
All three refer to the same barrier: absence of regulatory frameworks for circular economy.
These refer to the same national-level policy framework, with '2024' being a dated version.
These refer to the same national-level policy framework, with '2024' being a dated version.
Both refer to measurable outcomes of circular economy implementation.
Both refer to action/implementation plans as policy instruments. These are essentially the same type of document.
Business models that enable circular economy. While one is typed as Practice, business models are fundamentally enablers that facilitate circular practices.
Generic references to policy instruments and strategies at various levels.

merge_entries.canonical_label: Circular Economy Principles for Building Design
merge_entries.reasoning: Both refer to guidance/frameworks for designers applying circular economy principles.
All refer to the same physical materials/waste streams generated from construction and demolition activities. These are the actual material assets, not the management practices.
All refer to the same physical materials/waste streams generated from construction and demolition activities. These are the actual material assets, not the management practices.
All refer to the same physical materials/waste streams generated from construction and demolition activities. These are the actual material assets, not the management practices.
These are identical practices with slightly different abbreviations (CDW vs CDWM), both referring to the overall management approach for C&D waste.

These all refer to the same practice of designing and constructing buildings with circular economy principles. 'Circular Design' is the most concise canonical form, as it encompasses the design approach that enables circular construction.

These all refer to the same practice of designing and constructing buildings with circular economy principles. 'Circular Design' is the most concise canonical form, as it encompasses the design approach that enables circular construction.
Both refer to framework instruments that guide circular design implementation in the built environment.
Both refer to factors that facilitate or support circular economy implementation in construction.

These all refer to the same type of formal planning document/instrument used in construction projects. 'Waste Management Plan' is the standard term in construction governance. The singular/plural variations and 'Resource and Waste Management Plan' are the same instrument type.

These all refer to the same type of formal planning document/instrument used in construction projects. 'Waste Management Plan' is the standard term in construction governance. The singular/plural variations and 'Resource and Waste Management Plan' are the same instrument type.

These all refer to the same operational practice of managing, processing, and recovering waste and resources during construction/deconstruction activities. They describe the same core practice with slightly different terminology.

These all refer to the same operational practice of managing, processing, and recovering waste and resources during construction/deconstruction activities. They describe the same core practice with slightly different terminology.

These all refer to the same core practice of reusing materials in construction/deconstruction. The variations with 'recycling' and 'recovery' are essentially describing the same practice domain, as reuse is the primary activity and recycling is typically bundled with it in practice.

These all refer to the same core practice of reusing materials in construction/deconstruction. The variations with 'recycling' and 'recovery' are essentially describing the same practice domain, as reuse is the primary activity and recycling is typically bundled with it in practice.

These all refer to Australia's national-level waste policy instrument. 'National Waste Strategy 2018' and 'National Strategy for Waste and Recycling' are likely the same document (the official name is 'National Waste Policy' with various iterations including the 2018 strategy). These are the same policy instrument at the national level.

These all refer to Australia's national-level waste policy instrument. 'National Waste Strategy 2018' and 'National Strategy for Waste and Recycling' are likely the same document (the official name is 'National Waste Policy' with various iterations including the 2018 strategy). These are the same policy instrument at the national level.

These all refer to the core practice of taking buildings apart. 'Safe Disassembly' is just a qualified version of the same practice. 'Disassembly' as a Requirement is too generic and is better captured as the Practice itself.

These all refer to the core practice of taking buildings apart. 'Safe Disassembly' is just a qualified version of the same practice. 'Disassembly' as a Requirement is too generic and is better captured as the Practice itself.
Both refer to documented guidance/plans for how to disassemble a building. A disassembly manual is essentially a detailed disassembly plan. These are specific instruments that guide the practice.

Both refer to the same concept of technological methods/approaches for recycling materials. 'Advanced' is a qualifier that doesn't create a distinct entity. This is a Practice because it describes methods/approaches used in material processing.
Embodied carbon is a measurable outcome/KPI. 'Targets' for embodied carbon are still measuring the same metric - the target is just a threshold value of that metric.

These all refer to the same core practice of designing buildings/components to be easily taken apart. 'Design for Disassembly' and 'Design for Deconstruction' are synonymous terms in the construction domain. The variations mentioning 'reuse' and 'adaptability' are describing aspects of the same fundamental practice. This is a Practice (something people DO in design), not an Instrument or Enabler.

These all refer to the same core practice of designing buildings/components to be easily taken apart. 'Design for Disassembly' and 'Design for Deconstruction' are synonymous terms in the construction domain. The variations mentioning 'reuse' and 'adaptability' are describing aspects of the same fundamental practice. This is a Practice (something people DO in design), not an Instrument or Enabler.

These all refer to the same core practice of designing buildings/components to be easily taken apart. 'Design for Disassembly' and 'Design for Deconstruction' are synonymous terms in the construction domain. The variations mentioning 'reuse' and 'adaptability' are describing aspects of the same fundamental practice. This is a Practice (something people DO in design), not an Instrument or Enabler.

Both refer to mandatory planning/management requirements for construction waste. 'Construction Waste Management' as a Requirement is essentially the same obligation as requiring minimisation plans - they represent the requirement to manage/minimize waste, not the policies themselves.
Both refer to the same measurable outcome of reducing waste quantities. 'Waste Reduction Goal' is just a more specific phrasing of the same metric.
Both refer to the same practice of recovering value from waste materials. 'Waste Recovery Technologies' is simply the technological means of implementing waste recovery, not a separate concept.

These are different editions/versions of the same recurring policy instrument. The 2020 and 2022 versions are specific iterations of the National Waste Report series. The canonical label represents the instrument series itself.

These are different editions/versions of the same recurring policy instrument. The 2020 and 2022 versions are specific iterations of the National Waste Report series. The canonical label represents the instrument series itself.

All three refer to the same concept: EPR is a policy instrument/framework that makes producers responsible for end-of-life management of their products. While EPR creates requirements and influences practices, its PRIMARY function in governance is as a named policy instrument/mechanism. The 'Requirement:' prefix in one variant suggests it was extracted from a context describing EPR as a requirement, but EPR itself is the instrument that creates requirements.

All three refer to the same concept: EPR is a policy instrument/framework that makes producers responsible for end-of-life management of their products. While EPR creates requirements and influences practices, its PRIMARY function in governance is as a named policy instrument/mechanism. The 'Requirement:' prefix in one variant suggests it was extracted from a context describing EPR as a requirement, but EPR itself is the instrument that creates requirements.

All three entities refer to the same practice of managing building materials in a circular manner (keeping materials in use, recovering value, reducing waste). They are different phrasings of the same concept. The canonical label 'Circular Materials Management' better captures this as a specific practice without invoking the overarching 'Circular Economy' paradigm as the primary term. This represents the actual practice/method of handling materials circularly in construction and deconstruction contexts.

All three entities refer to the same practice of managing building materials in a circular manner (keeping materials in use, recovering value, reducing waste). They are different phrasings of the same concept. The canonical label 'Circular Materials Management' better captures this as a specific practice without invoking the overarching 'Circular Economy' paradigm as the primary term. This represents the actual practice/method of handling materials circularly in construction and deconstruction contexts.

These refer to the same concept: the financial cost of landfilling waste. While initially labeled differently, high landfill costs/charges actually ENABLE circular practices by making deconstruction and material recovery more economically competitive. The Enabler type is correct because increased costs create economic incentives for alternative approaches.

Both refer to the same material asset category - materials recovered from existing buildings. 'Quality' is a descriptor but doesn't make it a different entity; it's the same material asset with quality as an attribute

These refer to the same governmental entity. 'Australian Government Agencies' is simply a more specific reference to the organizational units within the Australian Government. Since this is a specific named organization that creates/enforces instruments, the correct type is Authority. The canonical label should be 'Australian Government' as it's the proper name of the authority, with agencies being implicit subdivisions.

These refer to the same concept - the requirement for products to be certified. 'Product Certification' is the specific obligation/mandate that products must meet certain standards, making it a Requirement. The word 'Policies' in the second entity is redundant - the certification requirement itself is what matters, not a separate policy instrument about certification. The primary function is the obligation to certify products, not a named policy document.

These refer to the same concept - the practice of using connections that can be disassembled. 'Reversible connections' is the more concise canonical form. This is a Practice (a specific method/approach used in construction) rather than a Requirement (which would be an obligation within a specific instrument). The longer form 'and assembly methods' is redundant as reversible connections inherently involve assembly methods.

These refer to the same concept - standard building contracts are contractual instruments used in construction. The first entity appears to describe a specific problematic aspect (specification of new materials) within these contracts that acts as a barrier to reuse, but the underlying entity is the contract instrument itself. The barrier is a characteristic of how the instrument is currently structured, not a separate entity.

These refer to the same concept - specific mandated targets for recycling waste materials. 'Waste Recycling Targets' is more precise and complete, as recycling targets in the construction/deconstruction context specifically refer to waste materials. Both are requirements that set obligations for recycling rates.

These refer to the same concept. 'Design for Flexibility' is a specific design practice/approach in construction that enables future adaptability. While 'Flexibility' alone could be seen as a requirement, in the context of building deconstruction governance it refers to the same practice of designing buildings to be adaptable. The more specific 'Design for Flexibility' is the better canonical label, and Practice is the correct type as it describes a specific design method/approach that practitioners implement.

These refer to the same circular economy design principle - a specific action/approach used in construction. 'Design Out Waste and Pollution' is the complete formulation of the first principle from the Ellen MacArthur Foundation's circular economy framework. 'Design Out Waste' is a shortened version of the same concept. This is a Practice (something practitioners DO during design) rather than an Enabler (which would be a factor that supports practices).

These refer to the same concept - a digital passport is a specific tool/mechanism (often mandated by policy) for tracking material information throughout a building's lifecycle. It functions as an instrument in the governance context because it's a standardized system/framework for documentation and information management, not a practice (which would be the ACT of using or implementing it). The singular form with title case is more standard.

These refer to the same concept. 'Building Materials and Components' is more comprehensive and precise, as it explicitly includes both raw materials and assembled components used in construction, which is the complete scope of physical resources in building deconstruction.

These refer to the same concept - the financial cost of disposing of materials/waste. While high disposal costs can act as a barrier to certain practices, the entity itself is fundamentally a measurable economic outcome. The primary nature is as a metric (cost/fee amount), and its barrier effect is contextual. 'Disposal Costs' is the more comprehensive term that encompasses fees.

merge_entries.canonical_label: Keep Products and Materials in Use
merge_entries.reasoning: Both refer to the same core circular economy practice of extending product/material lifecycles. The longer version includes 'Regenerate Nature' which is a separate principle. The core concept 'Keep Products and Materials in Use' is a specific action/approach in circular construction, making it a Practice. The shorter, more focused label is clearer and more commonly used in the domain.

These refer to the same concept - the traditional take-make-dispose economic model that acts as a barrier to circular economy and deconstruction practices. It is correctly typed as a Barrier because it represents the systemic obstacle that circular economy and building deconstruction seek to overcome. It is not a Practice (something people actively do), but rather the existing paradigm that prevents sustainable practices.

merge_entries.canonical_label: Maintain the Value of Products and Materials
merge_entries.reasoning: These refer to the same circular economy principle of keeping materials in circulation at their highest utility. This is a Practice (something people DO in construction/deconstruction) rather than a Requirement (which would be a specific mandate within a policy instrument). The action of maintaining value through reuse, refurbishment, and recycling is a practice that supports circular economy goals.

These refer to the same concept - the activity of identifying and categorizing materials. This is fundamentally a Practice (something people DO during deconstruction/construction processes) rather than a Requirement. The first label is more complete and descriptive, capturing both the identification and classification aspects of this practice.

These refer to the same concept - the practice of tracking materials through their lifecycle in construction/deconstruction. This is an ACTION/METHOD (tracking materials), not a measurable outcome. The outcome would be something like 'Material Recovery Rate' or 'Tracking Accuracy'. Material Tracking is what practitioners DO to enable circularity and material reuse.

These refer to the same concept - the phase in a building's lifecycle when it is in active use. This is a Practice (a stage of activity in the building lifecycle) rather than a Requirement (which would be a specific obligation). The terms 'Operation Phase' and 'Operational Phase' are synonymous, with 'Operation Phase' being the more standard terminology in building lifecycle management.

These refer to the same concept - the practice of conducting audits before demolition to assess materials and components. While pre-demolition audits can be required by regulations, the entity itself represents the actual practice/action of performing these audits. The primary nature is a Practice (something practitioners DO), though it may be mandated as a requirement in various jurisdictions.

These refer to the same core practice of extending material/component life through repair and reuse. 'Use, Reuse and Repair' includes 'Use' which is implicit in any practice context. The canonical form 'Repair and Reuse' is more concise and follows standard terminology in circular economy literature, where these are the key operational practices. Both describe the same action-oriented approach to material management.

These refer to the same concept - the capacity of systems to withstand and recover from disruptions. 'Systemic Resilience' is simply a more specific formulation of 'Resilience' in the context of building/construction systems. The correct type is OutcomeMetric because resilience is a measurable result or characteristic that governance frameworks aim to achieve, not something that enables other outcomes. It represents a desired state or performance indicator of the built environment system.

Both refer to the same physical infrastructure concept - facilities where deconstructed materials and components are stored. This is a MaterialAsset (physical resource/infrastructure) rather than a Practice (action) or Enabler (facilitating factor). The storage facilities themselves are the tangible asset that enables material reuse in the circular economy.

These refer to the same concept - a formal documented plan for systematically deconstructing a building. 'Deconstruction Plan' and 'Dismantling Plan' are synonymous terms used in different jurisdictions/contexts. The correct type is Instrument because it is a specific named policy document/deliverable required by regulations, not merely a requirement itself. The plan is the instrument that contains requirements.

These refer to the same concept - formal standards that govern materials and products in construction. 'Material and Product Standards' is more complete and accurate. The correct type is Instrument because standards are specific named policy tools/frameworks that establish requirements, rather than being requirements themselves. Standards are documents that contain multiple requirements within them.
